title: Multi-focus - difference in finch calls 2 dotplots

content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.The common house finch is a small songbird that begins to look for a mate in early winter. An ecologist plans to investigate the number of mating calls per minute for the finch during mating season. A previous report suggests the population distribution of the number of mating calls per minute for the finch is skewed to the right with mean <math alttext="mu equals 6.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 1.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Describe the sampling distribution of the sample mean number of mating calls per minute, <math alttext="x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>, for random samples of <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> finches from the population.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.The common house finch is a small songbird that begins to look for a mate in early winter. An ecologist plans to investigate the number of mating calls per minute for the finch during mating season. A previous report suggests the population distribution of the number of mating calls per minute for the finch is skewed to the right with mean <math alttext="mu equals 6.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 1.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Describe the sampling distribution of the sample mean number of mating calls per minute, <math alttext="x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>, for random samples of <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> finches from the population.

(b) Calculate and interpret the value of <math alttext="the probability of, x bar is greater than 6.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover><mo>></mo><mn>6.1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the question.

The ecologist performed a study to investigate whether there is a difference between the number of mating calls per minute for finches in one of two temperatures of the surrounding environment. The ecologist randomly assigned <math alttext="70" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> common house finches from a local zoo to be placed in one of two exhibits, with <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> placed in an exhibit with Temperature V and <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> placed in an exhibit with Temperature W. A zoo employee, who did not have knowledge of each finch’s assigned exhibit temperature, listened to one-minute recordings of each finch’s songs and counted the number of mating calls the finch made. The dotplots show the results of the study. (c) Based on the dotplots, write a few sentences comparing the distributions of the number of mating calls per minute for the finches placed in an exhibit with Temperature V and the finches placed in an exhibit with Temperature W.

The ecologist will conduct a hypothesis test to investigate whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that there is a difference between the two population means. Let <math alttext="mu sub V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean number of mating calls per minute for all finches similar to those used in the study who could be placed in an exhibit with Temperature V, and let <math alttext="mu sub W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean number of mating calls per minute for all finches similar to those used in the study who could be placed in an exhibit with Temperature W. The hypotheses for the test are as follows. <math alttext="H sub 0: mu sub V equals mu sub W. H sub a: mu sub V is not equal to mu sub W." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (d) After examining the two dotplots, the ecologist is concerned that a condition for the test may not be satisfied. Explain why the ecologist should not be concerned.

A <math alttext="90%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confidence interval for a difference between the population means (Temperature V minus Temperature W) is <math alttext="2.029 plus or minus 1.039" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.029</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>1.039</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Based on the confidence interval, what conclusion should the ecologist make for the hypothesis test? Justify your answer.

(f) Based on the conclusion from part (e), describe, in the context of the study, the type of error (Type <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> or Type <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) the ecologist might have made, and also describe a consequence of making this type of error.

topic.text: 1.9: Comparing Distributions of a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Compare distributions or relative positions of points within a distribution.
